facts.text: This appeal is directed against an appellate judgment of a Division Bench of the Madras High Court dated November 27, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Mukherjea, J. This appeal is directed against an appellate judgment of a Division Bench of the Madras High Court dated November 27, 1945, reversing the decision of the Subordinate Judge of Mayuram made in Original Suit No. 34 of 1943.

facts.text: The decision of the Subordinate Judge of Mayuram was made in Original Suit No. 34 of 1943.

anchor.surface_text: reversing the decision of the Subordinate Judge of Mayuram made in Original Suit No. 34 of 1943. There is numberdispute about the material facts of the case which lie within a short companypass and the companytroversy centers round one point only

facts.text: There is no dispute about the material facts of the case.

facts.text: Kothandarama Ayyar owned the properties in suit.

anchor.surface_text: to whom the properties in suit admittedly belonged. Kothandarama, who was a Hindu inhabitant of the District of Tanjore and owned companysiderable properties, died on 25th April 1905,

facts.text: Kothandarama was a Hindu inhabitant of the District of Tanjore.

anchor.surface_text: Kothandarama, who was a Hindu inhabitant of the District of Tanjore and owned companysiderable properties, died on 25th April 1905, leaving behind him as his near relations his adoptive mother Valu Ammal,

facts.text: Kothandarama died on 25th April 1905.

anchor.surface_text: properties, died on 25th April 1905, leaving behind him as his near relations his adoptive mother Valu Ammal, his widow Parbati and two daughters Nagammal and Gnanambal,

facts.text: Kothandarama left behind adoptive mother Valu Ammal, widow Parbati, daughters Nagammal and Gnanambal.

anchor.surface_text: died on 25th April 1905, leaving behind him as his near relations his adoptive mother Valu Ammal, his widow Parbati and two daughters Nagammal and Gnanambal, of whom Nagammal, who became a widow during the testators life time had an infant daughter named Alamelu.

facts.text: Nagammal became a widow during the testator's lifetime and had an infant daughter named Alamelu.

anchor.surface_text: Nagammal and Gnanambal, of whom Nagammal, who became a widow during the testators life time had an infant daughter named Alamelu. Kothandarama executed his last will on 13th March, 1905,

facts.text: Kothandarama executed his last will on 13th March 1905, genuineness not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: Kothandarama executed his last will on 13th March, 1905, and by this will, the genuineness of which is number disputed in the present litigation, he gave an authority to his widow to adopt unto him a son of his second daughter Gnanambal,

facts.text: The suit was commenced by Raju Ayyar, son of testator's nephews, taken in adoption by the widow in terms of the will.

anchor.surface_text: The suit, out of which the appeal arises, was companymenced by Raju Ayyar, who was a son of the testators nephews and was taken in adoption by the widow in terms of the will and it was for recovery of possession of certain properties, known as Kothangudi properties

facts.text: Suit for recovery of possession of Kothangudi properties, part of testator's estate.

anchor.surface_text: and it was for recovery of possession of certain properties, known as Kothangudi properties which formed part of the testators estate on the allegation that under the will mentioned above, these properties were given to Nagammal,

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged properties given to Nagammal for lifetime under will, no disposition of remainder, vested in plaintiff as adopted son and heir on Nagammal's death on 3rd January 1943.

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that under the will mentioned above, these properties were given to Nagammal, the widowed daughter of the testator for her life-time, but as there was numberdisposition of the remaining interest after the death of the life tenant, the properties vested in the plaintiff as the adopted son and heir of the deceased on the death of Nagammal which took place on 3rd of January, 1943.

facts.text: Nagammal died on 3rd of January 1943.

anchor.surface_text: on the death of Nagammal which took place on 3rd of January, 1943. Gnanambal, the second daughter of the testator, was the first and main defendant in the suit,

facts.text: Gnanambal, second daughter, first defendant, claimed no intestacy, entitled under will to properties absolute after Nagammal, subject to payment of Rs. 5000 to Alamelu.

anchor.surface_text: Gnanambal, the second daughter of the testator, was the first and main defendant in the suit, and she resisted the plaintiffs claim primarily on the ground that there was numberintestacy as regards the suit properties after the termination of the life interest of Nagammal, and that under the terms of the will itself she was entitled to get these properties in absolute right after the death of Nagammal, subject to payment of a sum of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu, the daughter of Nagammal.

facts.text: Alamelu was second defendant, died when suit pending in trial court, her heirs impleaded as defendants 3 to 9.

anchor.surface_text: Alamelu was made the second defendant in the suit and as she died when the suit was pending in the trial companyrt, her heirs were impleaded as defendants 3 to 9.

facts.text: First court (Subordinate Judge) accepted contention of defendant No. 1 and dismissed plaintiff's suit.

anchor.surface_text: The first companyrt accepted the companytention of the defendant No. 1 and dismissed the plaintiffs suit. On appeal to the High Court, the judgment was reversed and the plaintiffs claim was allowed.

facts.text: High Court reversed trial court judgment and allowed plaintiff's claim.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the High Court, the judgment was reversed and the plaintiffs claim was allowed. The defendant No. 1 has number companye up appeal to this companyrt.

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 appealed to Supreme Court.

facts.text: Will paragraph 5: Whole village of Kothangudi and house at Injigudi to Nagammal with life interest, after her to Gnanambal and her children on payment of Rs. 5000 to Alamelu.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 5, which is material for our present purposes runs as follows - The whole village of Kothangudi and the house at Injigudi, both of Nannilam Taluk, my daughter Nagammal, shall enjoy with life interest and after her the said property shall pass to my daughter Gnanambal and her children on payment by the latter of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu, Nagammals daughter.

facts.text: Will paragraph 13: Village of Kothangudi shall be enjoyed by Nagammal as stated in paragraph 5.

anchor.surface_text: By paragraph 13 provides that the village of Kothangudi shall be enjoyed by Nagammal as stated in paragraph 5.

facts.text: Widow adopted a son of the testator's nephews (plaintiff Raju Ayyar).

anchor.surface_text: was companymenced by Raju Ayyar, who was a son of the testators nephews and was taken in adoption by the widow in terms of the will

facts.text: Supreme Court held that paragraph 5 applies even when nephew's son is adopted, so Gnanambal entitled after Nagammal subject to Rs. 5000 payment.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the changes thus made the provisions of paragraphs 5, 6 and 7 would, in our opinion, still remain operative even if the person adopted was a nephews son of the testator.

facts.text: Nagammal enjoyed the Injigudi house for her life.

anchor.surface_text: If the whole of paragraph 5 remains operative the Injigudi house must also be deemed to have been given to Nagammal for her life and in fact the evidence is that she enjoyed it so long as she was alive.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, restored Subordinate Judge's decree.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal is allowed, the judgment and decree of the of the High Court are set aside and those of the Subordinate Judge restored.

facts.text: Will gave authority to widow to adopt son of Gnanambal before Jan 1908 or son of nephews.

anchor.surface_text: he gave an authority to his widow to adopt unto him a son of his second daughter Gnanambal, should she beget one before January, 1908, or in the alternative any of the sons of his two nephews, if the widow so chose.

The cardinal maxim to be observed by courts in construing a will is to endeavour to ascertain the intentions of the testator. This intentions has to be gathered primarily from the language of the document which is to be read as a whole without indulging in any conjecture or speculation as to what the testator would have done if he had been better informed or better advised.

concepts.interpretation: Gathered from language read as whole, considering surrounding circumstances as aid, but no conjecture; court must carry out expressed intentions without addition.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 5, which is material for our present purposes runs as follows - The whole village of Kothangudi and the house at Injigudi, both of Nannilam Taluk, my daughter Nagammal, shall enjoy with life interest and after her the said property shall pass to my daughter Gnanambal and her children on payment by the latter of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu, Nagammals daughter. By the sixth paragraph the Nallathukudi and Pungavur villages together with certain house property at Mayavaram are given to the testators adoptive mother and wife in equal shares to be enjoyed by both of them during their life-time and after their death they are to pass on to the adopted son.

concepts.interpretation: Provisions of paragraphs 5,6,7 applicable under all contingencies; read will as whole without excluding sets of provisions for different adoptions.

issues.text: Whether there was no disposition of the remaining interest in the Kothangudi properties after Nagammal's life interest under the will, with the properties vesting in the plaintiff as the adopted son and heir?

issues.text: Whether there was no intestacy as regards the suit properties after the termination of Nagammal's life interest, entitling Gnanambal to the properties in absolute right under the terms of the will subject to payment of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu?

anchor.surface_text: Gnanambal, the second daughter of the testator, was the first and main defendant in the suit, and she resisted the plaintiffs claim primarily on the ground that there was numberintestacy as regards the suit properties after the termination of the life interest of Nagammal, and that under the terms of the will itself she was entitled to get these properties in absolute right after the death of Nagammal, subject to payment of a sum of Rs. 5,000 to Alamelu, the daughter of Nagammal. Alamelu was made the second defendant in the suit and as she died when the suit was pending in the trial companyrt, her heirs were impleaded as defendants 3 to 9.

issues.text: Whether paragraph 5 of the will did not come into operation at all when the widow adopted a nephew's son instead of Gnanambal's son, making the disposition exclusively under paragraph 13?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on a construction of the will has found in favour of the plaintiff primarily on the ground that in the contingency which happened in the present case, viz., that the widow took in adoption a nephew son of the testator, paragraph 5 of the will did number companye into operation at all. The disposition as regards Kothangudi property is, therefore, to be found exclusively in paragraph 13 of the will and the actual words employed by the testator in that paragraph do number indicate that apart from Nagammals taking a life estate in the Kothangudi village the rest of the provisions in regard to this property as laid down in paragraph 5 would also be incorporated into paragraph 13.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second part of will (paras 11-16) modifies only adopted son's entitlements; no alteration to family provisions in paras 5,6,7; para 13 explicitly references para 5.

holdings.text: No change is made in paragraphs 11 to 16 with regard to the provision in paragraph 5 of the will. In paragraph 13 it is only stated that the village Kothangudi shall be enjoyed by Nagammal as stated in paragraph 5.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual reference in para 13 to para 5 without modification; affirmation does not exclude remainder provisions.

holdings.text: the disposition made in paragraphs 5, 6 and 7, which were in favour of the mother, the wife and the two daughters of the testator were meant to take effect immediately on the testators death. They were not contingent gifts in the sense of being made dependent upon the adoption of Gnanambals son by the wife of the testator.

anchor.surface_text: The position, therefore, seems to be that the disposition made in paragraphs 5, 6 and 7, which were in favour of the mother, the wife and the two daughters of the testator were meant to take effect immediately on the testators death. They were not contingent gifts in the sense of being made dependent upon the adoption of Gnanambals son by the wife of the testator.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions for widows and daughters immediate and non-contingent on adoption type; consistent across will's structure.

anchor.surface_text: The position, therefore, seems to be that the disposition made in paragraphs 5, 6 and 7, which were in favour of the mother, the wife and the two daughters of the testator were meant to take effect immediately on the testators death. They were not contingent gifts in the sense of being made dependent upon the adoption of Gnanambals son by the wife of the testator.
The result is that the appeal is allowed, the judgment and decree of the of the High Court are set aside and those of the Subordinate Judge restored.
